Class Key

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--java.awt.Component
        |
        +--java.awt.Container
              |
              +--java.awt.Window
                    |
                    +--java.awt.Frame
                          |
                          +--Key
All Implemented Interfaces:
javax.accessibility.Accessible, java.util.EventListener, java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.event.KeyListener, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable
public class Key
extends java.awt.Frame
implements java.awt.event.KeyListener

Modified by Mike Norton, 11/03/03, 11/05/03, 11/10/03.
Functional Purpose:

  • Displays a key pressed by the user,
  • 11/05/03; and deal with new lines.
  • 11/10/03; the font and its size will be passed from the command line.
  • 11/12/03; if invalit data are passed, the program will recognize them as invalid and use defaults.

Educational Purpose:
  • to work with the key handlers.
  • 11/10/03; to work with passing arguments from the command line.
  • 11/12/03; to work exception handling.

See Also:

Constructor Detail

Key

public Key(java.lang.String title,
           java.lang.String[] args)
Key constructs the Key object by passing the title to the frame, setting the passed font, and setting up the window in general. 11/12/03; If the data, for font size, are too small or invalid some how, they will be replaced with defaults.

Method Detail

main

public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
main declares a new Key object, sets the window size, and displays the Key object.

paint

public void paint(java.awt.Graphics g)
  • paint writes the characters in the "s" string to the screen, one at a time so they are editable later.
  • 11/05/03; if paint receives a new line character, it drops down the height of the font. Also, an underscore just sits at the end of the printed string, for effect.

    Overrides:
    paint in class java.awt.Container
